reviewText: An creative take on the horror anthology, but very frustrating to sit through. Interesting concept, but implemented in such a way that even the most dedicated watcher will have trouble getting (and staying) invested in what's happening.
Title: Summer School

reviewText: Horror fanatic Charles (Simon Wallace) takes a summer physics course at his high school. Charles keeps falling asleep in class, only to be plunged into a netherworld of gore and death. It appears that the other students have transformed into mutant killing machines! Now, Charles must fight for his life, at least until he wakes up in his classroom, safe and sound. Charles finds it increasingly difficult to tell his dreams from reality, since he's continually waking up into another hellish dream. His nightmares include zombies, spider-mutants, a machinegun-toting teacher, mass slaughter, decapitation, Nazis, a torture chamber, vampires, homicidal hillbillies, impalement by No. 2 pencil, gleeful disembowelment, and suicide-by-cop. SUMMER SCHOOL is not bad, but is pretty pointless overall. Gorehundts will probably love the drippy parts though...
Title: Summer School

reviewText: I had a great time watching this movie. Much better than most of its "class". Shot well and the actors did well. Good effort all round. I recommend possibly purchasing a good used copy of this movie from an Amazon vendor!
summary: Entertaining and very much worth watching more than once.......just wait a while
Title: Summer School

reviewText: This is not your typical low budget horror movie. Yes the effects are not as good as they should be, yes the movie could have been shot a little bit better but the like with a rare few low budget horror movies this one has a great story. I bought the DVD about 5 years ago and have let a lot of my friends borrow it and they all are blown away at how much they love the movie.
summary: A great independent horror movie with an awesome story.
Title: Summer School

reviewText: This film has a great ending...just what the horror buff ordered...but it took so long to take off, I'm not sure many viewers could last until the end.  If you like low-budget...but creative horror...this one's for you. It's not a film you'd want to see more than once...a good rental for a group of young fans.  2 1/2 stars!
Title: Summer School

reviewText: Usually I'm not one for dream sequences but this is really well done, each time Charlie falls asleep he has a dream. I know some people will be turned off hearing that, don't be because each dream is actually a short horror story, lots of scenarious. I really enjoyed this a lot
summary: A delicious Horror Banquet With Lots Of Variety
Title: Summer School

reviewText: nothing to write home about but was a good enough movie to keep my attention. Seen it many times before but then what movie now out is just a rehash of others made before it?
Title: Summer School

reviewText: Summer School (Ben Trandem, 2006)Clever take on the anthology-horror genre that would have been much better with a higher caliber of actor, but is still sharp and amusing enough for a rental. Charles (Simon Wallace) runs a movie review blog, and the night before summer school began, he spent his time catching up on horror flicks. He gets to his physics class early, slumps down, falls asleep, and then goes through a series of nightmares that mirror the plots of the movies he'd watched the night before, all featuring the other folks in the class: cute softball player Lindsey (Amy Cocchiarella), class burnouts Steve (Papier-Mache's Tony Czech) and Dennis (Lance Hendrickson), their teacher (Living Dead Girl's Jennifer Prettyman), and a cop who's in the building to make sure the burnouts stay in class (Fall into Me's Ty Richardson).Trandem did the frame, but each of the stories is done by a different person. One of the things that makes this movie interesting is that these are all first-timer directors who have industry experience in other parts of the job (Mike P. Nelson is a successful sound designer, most recently on Diners, Drive-Ins, and Dives; Hendrickson is an actor; Steve Rhoden is a make-up guy; Troy McCall is a cinematographer; Trandem is in special effects). And you kind of get what you'd expect; it feels a lot like a first movie of the "man, when directors do that, it's cool! We should do that!" variety, but you have to love the enthusiasm these guys bring to the table. That's also true for most of the actors (Cocchiarella has since gone on to production assistancy, and thank heaven for that. Gorgeous, but not an actor). Don't get me wrong, as should be obvious you can't go into this expecting Winter's Bone, because you will inevitably be disappointed. But as long as you're used to low-budget amateur horror flicks, you'll get a kick out of this one. ***
summary: Inventive, but amateur (and not a remake).
Title: Summer School
